combTMB 0.0.0.9000

    Adjust glm models

    combTMBglm.Rd

    Adjust glm models

    Usage

    combTMBglm(
  formula,
  family = gaussian(link = "identity"),
  data = NULL,
  starting_val = "zero",
  contrasts = NULL,
  weights = NULL,
  size = NULL,
  offset = NULL,
  dofit = TRUE,
  map = NULL,
  silent = TRUE,
  control = combTMBcontrol(),
  na.action
)

    Arguments

    formula

    An object of class "formula" describe the model for mean.

    family

    An character indicating the model used. Options are model Poisson:"poisson", negative binomial type 2 "nb2", and binomial "binomial" - see Details.

    data

    An optional data frame containing the variables in the model. If missing data, the variables ara taken from environment(formula).

    starting_val

    An character indicating which method should be used to provide initial values. Options are the estimated values through a fitted model using glm.fit "fm" and all initial parameter values are zero "zero".

    contrasts

    An optional list. See the contrasts.arg of model.matrix.default.

    weights

    An optional vector of "prior weights" to be used in the fitting process. Should be NULL or a numeric vector - see Details.

    size

    Number of trials in binomial model.

    offset

    A numeric vector representing the model offset.

    dofit

    Fit the model (`TRUE`) or return the processed data without fitting (`FALSE`)?

    map

    xxx.

    silent

    Silent or include optimization details? Helpful to set to `FALSE` for models that take a while to fit.

    control

    Optimization control options via combTMBcontrol.

    na.action

    a function that specifies how to handle observations containing NAs. The default action (na.omit, inherited from the 'factory fresh' value of getOption("na.action")) strips any observations with any missing values in any variables. Using na.action = na.exclude

    Value

    retorna a um objeto da classe combTMBglm.

    Details

    • Link function: Options are link="log", link="logit", link="probit" and link="cloglog".

    • binomial models can be specified typically a two-column matrix cbind(successes,failures)~... form or prob ~ ..., weights = N.

    • In the case of the family gaussian. Weights \(w_i\) are normalized by multiplying them by \(\frac{n}{\sum_{i=1}^{n}w_i}\), where n is the sample size. Thus, the estimated covariance matrix of the parameter estimators is scale invariant of the `weights` variable.
